success_criteria: alt attribute is missing in iframe or img tag

error_fixes.problem_type: alt attribute is missing in img tag
error_fixes.CoT:
Sure, to find the accessibility issue related to the missing `alt` attribute in the `iframe` tag or the `img` tag, we need to:

1. Review the `iframe` and `img` tags in the provided HTML code.
2. Check if there is an `alt` attribute present for the `img` tag.
3. Check if there is an `alt` attribute present for the `iframe` tag.

Let me review the code and look for the missing `alt` attributes in the `img` and `iframe` tags.

success_criteria: input element or button is missing an associated label, it contains an alt attribute, or its label is empty

error_fixes.problem_type: input element or button is missing an associated label, it contains an alt attribute, or its label is empty
error_fixes.CoT:
Sure, let's go step by step in finding the accessibility issue related to the input element or button:
1. Check if all input elements and buttons have associated labels.
2. Check if the alt attribute is correctly used for images inside buttons or inputs.
3. Ensure that the labels are not empty.
Let's start by checking the input elements and buttons to see if any of them have an associated label.

success_criteria: Audio or video element should avoid automatically playing audio
fixed_example:
<video controls>
<source src="bookstore-video.mp4" type="video/mp4">
Your browser does not support the video tag.
</video>

error_fixes.problem_type: Audio or video element should avoid automatically playing audio
error_fixes.fixed_line: <iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/your-exercise-video" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen allow="accelerometer; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>
error_fixes.CoT:
1. Look for any `<audio>` or `<video>` elements in the HTML code.
2. Check if there are any attributes within these elements that specify autoplay functionality.
3. If autoplay is set, ensure that it is appropriate and considerate, especially for users who may have sensory sensitivities or who rely on screen readers.
4. Make recommendations on either removing the autoplay attribute or providing controls for the user to manually play the audio or video content.

success_criteria: <b> <i> or <font> tag should not be used

error_fixes.CoT:
Step 1: Identify any instances of <b>, <i>, or <font> tags in the HTML code.
Step 2: Check if these tags are used for styling purposes.
Step 3: If any of these tags are found to be used solely for styling, they should be replaced with appropriate CSS attributes.
Step 4: Make the necessary changes to ensure that styling is done using CSS instead of inline or deprecated HTML tags.

success_criteria: onmousedown event missing onkeydown event or script is not keyboard accessible

error_fixes.problem_type: onmousedown event missing onkeydown event or script is not keyboard accessible
error_fixes.CoT:
1. Look for any `onmousedown` event handlers within the HTML.
2. Check if there are corresponding `onkeydown` event handlers for keyboard accessibility.
3. Identify if any scripts or functions are not keyboard accessible.
4. Determine if any actions or events are dependent on mouse interactions only.
5. Suggest adding `onkeydown` event handlers or adjusting scripts for keyboard accessibility.

success_criteria: meta refresh with a time-out is used.

Step 1: Locate the <title> element in the HTML code.
Step 2: Check if the <title> element is empty or missing a title text.

success_criteria: document language not identified or incorrect

error_fixes.CoT:
To address the issue of document language not being identified or being incorrect, we need to ensure that the language attribute is included in the HTML tag at the beginning of the document. 

1. Check if the <html> tag includes the "lang" attribute with the correct language code.
2. If the "lang" attribute is missing or incorrect, we need to add or correct it to specify the language of the document. 

Let's go ahead and identify if there is an issue related to the document language in the provided HTML code.

success_criteria: input element has more than one associated label

error_fixes.problem_type: Input element has more than one associated label
error_fixes.CoT:
Sure, let's go step by step to identify the issue of having an input element with more than one associated label:

Step 1: Identify the input element(s) in the form. In this case, we have three input elements:
- Input element with id="name"
- Input element with id="email"
- Textarea element with id="message"

Step 2: Find the associated label(s) for each input element. 
- The input element with id="name" does not have any associated label.
- The input element with id="email" has labels with the same 'for' attribute value "email".
- The textarea element with id="message" does not have any associated label.

Step 3: Determine which input element has more than one associated label. 
- The input element with id="email" has two labels associated with it, both using the 'for' attribute value "email".

So, the identified issue is that the input element with id="email" has more than one associated label, which is an accessibility concern. It's important to have a clear association between input elements and their respective labels for assistive technologies to correctly interpret the form inputs.
